importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The date of the news report indicates the most current update on the flooding situation, showing the ongoing impact and response efforts in Mexico.

keyTakeAways: At least 64 people have died in Mexico due to heavy rains and flooding in five states.
The National Civil Protection Coordination (CNPC) chief, Laura Velazquez Alzua, reported 65 people still missing.
Veracruz confirmed 29 deaths, followed by 21 in Hidalgo, 13 in Puebla, and one in Queretaro.
43 people are missing in Hidalgo, 18 in Veracruz, and 4 in Puebla.
Thousands of military troops have been deployed across the five affected states to provide emergency assistance.
Governors are coordinating support and response efforts.
About 100,000 houses have been affected, with some near rivers reportedly 'practically disappeared'.
The flooding was linked to remnants of Hurricane Priscilla and Tropical Rainstorm Raymond, which caused rivers to rise rapidly.
The heaviest rainfall occurred in Cerro Azul, Veracruz (280mm) and Cuetzalan del Progreso, Puebla (286mm).
The Mexican Army, Air Force, and National Guard have jointly responded, distributing food and clean water via air and ground in inaccessible areas.
Nearly 400 repair workers have restored over 80% of electricity supply for about 263,000 affected users.
President Claudia Sheinbaum stated there were no prior meteorological warnings indicating such heavy rainfall.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Mexico has suffered significant loss of life and infrastructure damage due to severe flooding in five states—Veracruz, Hidalgo, Puebla, and Queretaro—caused by heavy rains linked to remnants of Hurricane Priscilla and Tropical Rainstorm Raymond. At least 64 people have died, with 65 still missing, and over 100,000 homes affected. The heaviest rainfall occurred in Cerro Azul and Cuetzalan del Progreso. Government agencies and military forces have deployed emergency aid, including food, clean water, and power restoration, with about 80% of electricity services restored. President Claudia Sheinbaum and CNPC Chief Laura Velazquez Alzua highlighted the lack of prior meteorological warnings, raising concerns about early warning systems.
title: Mexico flooding death toll rises to 64, with dozens still missing
